awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity to Support Elementary CS Pathways Tailored to Rural Needs in Idaho
awd_abstract_narration:
Elementary computer science education is crucial for initiating and maintaining students’ interest in and positive attitudes toward computing. Children as young as five can understand basic computer science and programming concepts, yet only a quarter of elementary schools across the nation offer computer science instruction. Rural communities often have specific needs around computing education related to smaller populations, depressed economies, and a high number of families living in poverty. This partnership between American Institutes for Research, Idaho STEM Action Center, and BootUp Professional Development will support rural districts in Idaho in the design of an inclusive, K-5 computer science course pathway. The project team will collaborate to deepen their partnership, while engaging with district- and school-level partners from rural communities to define future directions for supporting the pathway.

This research-practitioner partnership between American Institutes for Research, Idaho STEM Action Center, and BootUp Professional Development will develop the Idaho Elementary CS Collaborative (IECC) to support the design of K–5 computer science pathways in Idaho school districts. The IECC will address challenges to CS pathway development particular to low-income, rural communities, such as resource scarcity and relatively low exposure to CS among students. Project activities include facilitated partnership meetings to build the RPP; a landscape review of elementary computer science in Idaho; and the development of a set of CS planning and learning opportunities for administrators, teachers, and families.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The Idaho STEM Action Center, BootUp Professional Development, and the American Institutes for Research® (AIR®) formed a research–practice partnership in fall 2022 to explore the strengths and challenges rural Idaho districts would bring to developing computer science (CS) instructional pathways for their K–6 schools, teachers, and students. The partnership—called the Idaho Elementary Computer Science Collaborative (IECC)—conducted landscape surveys, interviews, and a focus group to learn more about these strengths and challenges, as well as the conditions and supports that would facilitate elementary CS pathway development. We define elementary CS pathways as organized, coherent sequences of CS learning experiences that support all students in learning increasingly complex CS ideas—often defined in state-adopted CS content standards—as students move through their elementary education.

Analysis across data sources resulted in five key findings. The first finding relates to the current state of elementary CS education across Idaho: CS education efforts are inconsistent and usually do not form coherent elementary CS pathways. The next two findings highlight two challenges faced by Idaho districts that likely relate to their rural context: Resource scarcity is a major barrier for elementary CS pathways in Idaho districts, and some (though not all) education interest holders perceive low community support for CS education. The fourth finding highlights strong interest among educators in advancing elementary CS education in Idaho—an important strength to leverage in pathway development. The final finding relates to a support that could facilitate pathway development: Rural districts that participated in the project had existing industry partnerships related to education, and survey data indicated that many were interested in expanding those partnerships to include CS.

These results suggest two approaches for addressing challenges faced by rural districts in Idaho: communication and partnerships. First, facilitating communication among district leaders, classroom educators, and community members may contribute to building shared understanding and a common vision for elementary CS education. The IECC’s landscape surveys showed that district superintendents—who have the authority to make wider and more systematic changes within districts—tended to believe that students’ families did not value CS. Surveys showed that more participating superintendents held this belief than participating principals and teachers. This may reflect superintendents’ more distal relationships with students and families, as teachers who interacted frequently with students and families believed that families valued CS education. This study's findings suggest that if superintendents spend more time speaking to elementary students and families about CS instruction, they may better understand the actual level of interest and therefore may move to allocate more resources to CS instruction.

Second, this study’s findings suggest that creating sustainable, long-term partnerships between local industries and elementary schools may support districts creating locally relevant, meaningful elementary CS pathways for students. In our interviews with district leaders from five Idaho districts, all five shared ways in which they already partnered with local industries in educational efforts that connect to their own communities, noting the value of these connections for students. These existing partnerships suggest a strong foundation for future partnerships dedicated to CS education between industry and schools. Further, the IECC’s focus group with industry representatives demonstrated that some companies and organizations would be interested in exploring such a partnership. The industry focus group also provided specific strategies for helping to build school–industry partnerships, such as including a state partner like Idaho STEM Action Center that could support broad impacts.

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2025
Modified by: Kathryn M Rich
